Description: Body sherd of large Chian Mature Animal Style pottery chalice or heavy chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black with lotus flower in added white outline and added red centre; exterior, from top: dot and billet pattern; broken maeander band between black bands; painted decoration consisting of bull (part of rump with patterned decoration and tail remaining) to right; pendant roundels, triangles and rosette as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

According to Fairbanks the sherd comes from a krater and possibly depicts a lion. However, the sherd may come from a large chalice or heavy chalice and the pattern on the animal's body is that which is typically found on bulls. For parallels regarding the decoration, see New York Metropolitan Museum of Art 55.71.8 from Naukratis.
